coredata.dc:title: Quantum corrections to induced light scattering and the second virial coefficient of water and hydrogen sulfide
coredata.dc:creator: De Santis, A.
Gregori, A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Some model pair potentials of liquid water and hydrogen sulfide have been used for computing second virial coefficients, lowdensity values of depolarized light scattering due to the dipole-induced-dipole (DID) mechanism, mean-square torques and mean-square forces versus temperature. The second virial coefficient and depolarized scattering were corrected to account for quantum effects, which are found to be relevant in the case of water. The “MCY” water pair potential gives values of the second virial coefficient in good agreement with experiment, while computed and experimental values of the DID intensity disagree significantly. Possible reasons for this discrepancy are discussed.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 160, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LE17ERS 28 July 1989 QUANTUM CORRECTIONS TO INDUCED LIGHT SCATTERING AND THE SECOND VIRLAL COEFFICIENT OF WATER AND HYDROGEN SULFIDE A. DE SANTIS and A. GREGORI Facolta DiAgraria, Universita Della Tuscia, Via Riello, 01100 Viterbo, Italy Received 23 March 1989; in final form 22 May 1989 Some model pair potentials of liquid water aad hydrogen sulfide have been used for computing second virial coefficients, low- density values of depolarized Light scattering due to the dipole induced-dipole (DID) mechanism, mean-square torques and mean-square forces versus temperature. The second virial coefficient and depolarized scattering were corrected to account for quantum cifects, which are found to be relevant in the case of water. The MCV water pair potential gives values of risc second vinaI coefficient in good agreement with experiment, while computed and experimental values of the DID intensity disagree significantly, Possible reasons for this discrepancy are discussed. 1, IntroductIon In recent years, several intermolecular potential models for liquid water and hydrogen sulfide have been developed [1 4] and used for the simulation of different physical properties of these fluids. Such models have also been used in the gas phase for com- paring computed and experimental second virial coefficients [5], although it is commonly recognized that effective pair potentials for the condensed phase cannot reproduce accurately the gas phase proper- ties. For monatomic and diatoniic fluids computed second virial coefficients are systematically more positive than experimental ones [6]; the difference is probably due to many-body interactions in the condensed phase, where the potential parameters are fitted. In contrast, systematically more negative val- ues have been obtained in the case of water (5], the discrepancy with experiment reaching about 50% for the lowest temperature. This large discrepancy can be explained for effective pair potentials fitted to the liquid but is quite puzzling for those potentials ob- tained from numerical fits to the dimer properties. The first object of this study is to show that quan- tum corrections significantly reduce the discrepancy between the computed and experimental second vi- rial coefficients of water and that reasonable agree- ment with the experimental data is obtained with the MCY [2] potential, in contrast with previous findings (5]. The second object is to extend the cal- culations to the light scattering intensity. Very re- cently, a new band has been discovered in water va- pour [7] and interpreted in terms of the dipole induced-dipole (DID) scattering mechanism. We will show that, for the DID intensity, the difference be- tween the model results and experimental data is sig- nificantly reduced by quantum corrections. Remain- ing deviations from experimental data are briefly discussed. For the sake of completeness, comparison between the potential model predictions and exper- imental data is extended to gaseous hydrogen sul- fide. The H20 and }42S molecules are quite similar in structure, dipole moment and polarizabilities, and both give rise to similar DID lineshapes in the liquid phase [81. Therefore it is interesting to extend the comparison between the two fluids, begun in the liq- uid phase, to the low density phase. 2. Results and discussions The classical second vinaI coefficient is given by [9] 55 o 009-2614/89/S 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. In eq. (2) V(R, Q1, Q2) is the intermolecular pair potential, k the Boltzmann constant and T the ab- solute temperature. In refs. [10,11], quantum cor- rections to the classical pair distribution function are reported up to order h2. When applied to B~1( T), they give [9] B0(T)=B~1(T) (r ~ \dR j n where for simplicity of notation the subscript O has been suppressed and < >~ denotes (2) <A>0rj Ago(R,Qt,Q2) dQ1 ctQ2. The pair potential models we have used are taken from refs. [1,2] for water, and from refs. (3,4] for hydrogen sulfide. The models of refs. The potential of Matsuoka, Clementi and Yoshimine (MCY) [2] has been derived by fitting where < > denotes the classical configurational av- erage, ( >~ the low-density limit of < > /p, p is the density, F is the force, M is the molecular mass and Va and 1~ are, respectively, the principal a and aa components of the torque and of the momentum of inertia tensor in the fixed-body reference frame. In the low-density limit and within a simplified scheme which neglects orientational correlations, the depolarized light scattering due to the DID media- nism is proportional to [12] the results of ab initio quantum mechanical calcu- lations on the water dimer. The electrostatic part is similar to the semi-empirical function of eq. (6), while the remaining part is parameterized in terms of three atom atom potentials. In this work, the pa- rameter set of ref. 113] has been used. The fixed-body reference frame has been chosen with the y axis perpendicular to the molecular plane and the x and z axis perpendicular and parallel to the main symmetry axis, respectively. The origin coin- cides with the molecular centre of mass. The inte (S2 >~ grations of eqs. [3,4~ T Potential Bd B0 <Sa>d 1022( r~)/kT(K) model (cm3/mol) (cm3/mol) (nm3) (J/amg) 1022(n /kT (Jfamg) 1022<t~>/kT (J/amg) 10(F2>/kT (N2/J amg) 30 4C 178 175 36.6 0.543 3C 232 222 57.5 2.38 exp. 165 33 0.558 2.30 0.415 0.741 0.452 0.752 453 4C 76.2 75.5 28,1 0.303 3C 73.5 71.8 35.1 1,11 exp. 78 0.316 1.12 0.231 0.467 0.339 0.399 g r Table 1 Computed classical and quantum-corrected secoiad vinai coefficients (8~~ and B0), light scattering parameters <S2>,~1, (S2 )~). mean$qtsarc torque components ((na> ) and mean-square forces (<F2>) for watet in the low-density limit. The potential models are taken from rel s, [1,2]. The density is in amagat (amg) unit (I amg=2.687X 1025 particles/rn3) Volume 160, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LEflERS 28 July 1989 water are due to Kell et al. [14] with exclusion of the lowest temperature value, which is an extrapolated result quoted in ref. [5]. Experimental B (T) data for hydrogen sulfide have been estimated from the PVT data of ref. (151. A linear fit to the compress- ibility values over increasing ranges of density de- termines 8(T) with an accuracy of 2%. The exper- imental <82> data have been calculated from the DID tight scattering intensities [7,16]. The two potential models 3C [3] and 4C [4] yield quite different values of B( T) and (82> for hydro- gen sulfide (table 2). The 4C model gives better agreement with experimental data and the experi- mental value of (82> is well reproduced. For both models the quantum-corrected results for (S2> are practically the same as the classical ones since the torque corrections are small, and those due to the forces are negligible. In contrast the quantum corrections are important in the case of water, and range from a maximum of 27% at 373 K to a minimum of 5% at 673 K (see table 1). Such corrections are essentially due to the torques, which are one or two orders of magnitude higher than those in H2S at the same temperature. The computed classical values of both (S2> and B( T) approach the experimental data when quan- tum corrections are applied. The superiority of the MCY model over the TIP4P appears evident (see table 1). The MCY classical values for B( T) agree with previous determinations of ref. E 5]. Minor dis- crepancies are probably due to the small differences in the potential parameters quoted in refs. [2,13]. The quantum-corrected 8(T) values are in good agreement with experiment as expected for a poten- tial model fitted to the results of ab initio quantum mechanical calculations on the water dimer [2]. This fact overcomes to a large extent previous uncertain- ties regarding the MCY potential E 5,17] and stresses the important role of quantum corrections for water. The experimental value for <52> is smaller than the computed one (see table 1). The discrepancy Is about 40% and exceeds the experimental uncer- tainty; more significantly, it exceeds the correspond- ing discrepancy between the experimental and com- puted B( T) values. This fact is not attributable to the approximate form of eq. (5) which neglects force corrections. In fact, quantum corrections to B( T) due to the forces are an order of magnitude smaller than those due to the torques. Therefore it is reasonable to neglect the force corrections to the classical (82> values. In our opinion, the reason for the discrep- ancy could be the separation process followed in ref. E 7]. Two main checks are possible. Firstly, calcu- lation of the quantum free rotor spectrum should permit a more refined analysis of the low-frequency region, where allowed and induced contributions overlap and may prevent possible systematic errors on (82>. Secondly, the induced cross contributions [12], completely neglected in ref E 7], could play a non-negligible rote in renormalizing the integrated intensities for orientational and/or DID contribu- tions. Work in these directions is currently in progress. 3. Summary We have shown that the agreement between the- oretical and experimental values of the second virial coefficients B( T) arid the induced light scattering parameter <Sa> for water can be significantly im- proved by making quantum corrections to the clas- sical configuration averages. The superiority of the ab initio MCY potential with respect to empirical ones is evident from the B (T) temperature behav- iour. Empirical potentials yield values of (S2> a fac- tor of two higher than the experimental values [7]. The use of the MCY potential reduces the discrep- ancy to less than 50% and the interpretation of the induced light scattering in terms of the DID mech- anism is strongly supported. However, such a dis- crepancy is still too large when compared to the dif- ference between theoretical and experimental values for B( T). We believe that a more refined analysis of the experimental light scattering data is necessary in order to obtain a more precise separation of the in- duced spectral contributions from the allowed ro- tational ones. head.ce:title: Quantum corrections to induced light scattering and the second virial coefficient of water and hydrogen sulfide

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Facoltà Di Agraria, Università Della Tuscia, Via Riello, 01100 Viterbo, Italy

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Some model pair potentials of liquid water and hydrogen sulfide have been used for computing second virial coefficients, lowdensity values of depolarized light scattering due to the dipole-induced-dipole (DID) mechanism, mean-square torques and mean-square forces versus temperature. The second virial coefficient and depolarized scattering were corrected to account for quantum effects, which are found to be relevant in the case of water. The “MCY” water pair potential gives values of the second virial coefficient in good agreement with experiment, while computed and experimental values of the DID intensity disagree significantly. Possible reasons for this discrepancy are discussed.

ce:other-ref.ce:textref: T.R. Forester, I.R. McDonald and M.L. Klein, to be published.
